issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the income derived from letting of the building constructed on Plot No. 7 is properly to be computed under section 9, 10 or under section 12 of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the income derived from letting of the building constructed on Plot No. 7 is properly to be computed under section 9, 10 or under section 12 of the Income -tax Act.

issues.text: whether the assessment should be made under s. 10 as of income from a business

anchor.surface_text: The first contention of the appellant, as already seen, is that the assessment should be made tinder s. 10 as of income from a business.

issues.text: whether, the building is to be assessed under s. 9 which of course will have to be on the basis of its annual value or whether the rent from the building has to be assessed under s. 12 after the allowances mentioned in sub-s. 4 have been deducted

anchor.surface_text: The only dispute that then remains is whether, the building is to be assessed under s. 9 which of course will have to be on the basis of its annual value or whether the rent from the building has to be assessed under s. 12 after the allowances mentioned in sub-s.  4  have been deducted.

issues.answer: under s. 12 after allowances in sub-s. 4

issues.text: does the present letting come within the term of sub-s. 4 of s. 12 ?

anchor.surface_text: The next question is, does the present letting come within the term of sub-s.  4  of s. 12 ? That provision requires two conditions, namely, that the furniture should be let and also buildings and the letting of the buildings should be inseparable from the letting of the furniture.
Now here both furniture and building have no doubt been let. The question is, are they inseparably let?

issues.text: The question in this appeal is how the income received as rent and hire is to be assessed, that is, under which section of the Income-tax Act, 1922 is it assessable.

anchor.surface_text: The question in this appeal is how the income received as rent and hire is to be assessed, that is, under which section of the Income-tax Act, 1922 is it assessable.

arguments.claim: The entire income should be assessed under s. 10 as the income of a business

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contends that the entire income should be assessed under s. 10 as the income of a business or, in the alternative, the income should be assessed under s. 12 as income from a residuary source,

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer held that the building had to be assesses under s. 9 as it was the specific section covering it and there was, therefore, no scope for resorting to the residuary section, s. 12,

arguments.claim: Rent from building assessable under s.12(4) only where letting of furniture and fixtures made it indispensable to let the building also; not the case here so s.9 applies

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner held on appeal that the rent from a building could only be assessed under s. 12 with the allowances mentioned in sub-s.  4  where for the letting of the furniture and fixtures it was indispensable to let the building also and as that was not the case here the building had been rightly assessed under s. 9 .

arguments.claim: Several heads of income in s.6 and ss.7-12 are mutually exclusive; income assignable to one head only

anchor.surface_text: Now, it is beyond dispute that the several heads of income mentioned in s. 6 of the Act and dealt with separately in ss. 7 to 12 are mutually exclusive, each head being specific to cover the income arising from a particular source and that it cannot be said that any one of these sections is more specific than another-. see United Commercial Bank Ltd.

arguments.claim: Letting out of a commercial asset is a business; fully equipped hotel building is commercial asset; lease covenants show carrying on business

anchor.surface_text: The appellant put the matter in this way. Letting out of a commercial asset is a business and what it did was to let out a commercial asset, namely, a fully equipped hotel building. It also said that the lessors covenants in the lease showed that in making the lease, the appellant was carrying on a business and not letting out property.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ary letting in the present case was of the building and, therefore, deprived the appellant of the benefit of s. 12  4 . We may state here that the Tri

arguments.court_reasoning: No test from cases; each case on facts; not business from owner's exploitation view; distinguished prior business cases

arguments.claim: Company objects and certain lease clauses/memo show lease amounted to carrying on business

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant also relied on certain clauses in the lease and a clause in the memorandum of the appellant company to show that the lease amounted to the carrying on of a business.

arguments.court_reasoning: Clauses are ordinary for furnished building lease; no service rendered or business done

arguments.claim: s.12(4) takes income from inseparable letting of building with furniture out of s.9 into residuary s.12 via harmonious construction to give effect to provision

anchor.surface_text: If sub-s.  4  of s. 12 is to have any effect-and it is the duty of the court so to construe every part of a statute that it has effect-it must be held that the income arising from the letting of a building in the circumstances mentioned in it is an income coming within the residuary head.

arguments.claim: Primary letting must be of furniture with building letting incidental/secondary; here primary was building so no s.12(4)

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the primary letting in the present case was of the building and, therefore, deprived the appellant of the benefit of s. 12(4). ... Tribunal had thought ... primary letting was of the machinery and the letting of the building was only incidental

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ess which latter would be for effecting repairs to them or for replacing them where it was the duty of the lessee to do so under the lease. We think,

arguments.court_reasoning: No language support for primary/incidental; slender foundation from order of mention

arguments.claim: Inseparable in s.12(4) means machinery/plant/furniture affixed to building by nature so necessarily let together

anchor.surface_text: It was suggested on behalf of the respondent Commissioner that the sub-section contemplates a case where the machinery, plant or furniture are by their nature inseparable from a building so that if the machinery, plant or furniture are let, the building has also necessarily to be let along with it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: from the letting of the furniture and fixtures. We think that the lease satisfies all the companyditions for the applicability of s. 12 4  and is comp

arguments.court_reasoning: Language is letting inseparable, not affixed; always possible to separate; intention governs

arguments.claim: Inseparable letting in s.12(4) determined by intention of parties: enjoyed together, practically one letting, not let separately

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the inseparability referred to in sub-s.  4  is an inseparability arising from the intention of the parties. That intention may be ascertained by framing the following questions: Was it the intention ... that the two should be enjoyed together? Was it the intention to make the letting of the two practically one letting? Would one have been let alone ...

arguments.claim: Lease satisfies conditions of s.12(4): furniture/building let inseparably per intention from clauses e.g. cl.1(a), cl.1(h)

holdings.text: The income under the lease cannot be assessed under s. 10 of the Act as the income of a business.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts of this case we are unable to agree that the letting of the building amounted to the doing of a business. The income under the lease cannot, therefore be assessed under s. 10 of the Act as the income of a business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letting out fully equipped hotel building by owner who never operated hotel business is not exploitation as business; distinguished prior cases involving temporary letting of previously operated factories/mills; company objects and lease covenants insufficient.

holdings.text: The several heads of income mentioned in s. 6 of the Act and dealt with separately in ss. 7 to 12 are mutually exclusive, each head being specific to cover the income arising from a particular source.

anchor.surface_text: Now, it is beyond dispute that the several heads of income mentioned in s. 6 of the Act and dealt with separately in ss. 7 to 12 are mutually exclusive, each head being specific to cover the income arising from a particular source and that it cannot be said that any one of these sections is more specific than another-.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established principle confirmed with reference to United Commercial Bank Ltd. v. CIT; income assignable to only one head, specific excludes residuary unless exception applies.

holdings.text: When a building and plant, machinery or furniture are inseparably let the Act contemplates the rent from the building as a residuary head of income under s.12 notwithstanding s.9.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that when a building and plant, machinery or furniture are inseparably let the Act contemplates the rent from the building as a residuary head of income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction to give effect to s.12(4); otherwise provision redundant as s.9 taxes on annual value irrespective of letting; owner-tenant via s.10(2)(vi) depreciation confirms applicability to owners.

holdings.text: Sub-s.4 of s.12 does not require primary letting of furniture/machinery with building incidental; no such language support.

anchor.surface_text: Now the difficulty that we feel in accepting the view which appealed to the High Court and the Tribunal is that we find nothing in the language of sub-s. 4 of s. 12 to support it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order of mention and 'also' too slender; impossible for building letting to be incidental to furniture; must apply equally to plant/machinery cases.

holdings.text: Inseparability under s.12(4) is from intention of parties, ascertained by: (1) intention to enjoy together? (2) practically one letting? (3) one let without other? Affirmative-affirmative-negative = inseparable.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the inseparability referred to in sub-s. 4 is an inseparability arising from the intention of the parties. That intention may be ascertained by framing the following questions: Was it the intention ...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects 'affixed by nature' as unworkable (always separable); language 'letting inseparable' focuses on parties' intent; justifies shift from s.9 as new income type from composite letting.

holdings.text: The lease satisfies all the conditions for the applicability of s. 12(4) and is covered by it; building and furniture inseparably let.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Intention clear from cl.1(a) (use together for hotel), cl.1(h) (no removal except hotel purposes); separate rent/hire insufficient; renewal/fire clauses addressed, covered by other provisions.

holdings.text: Rent from building computed under s.12(4) with allowances; furniture hire under s.12(3); no part under s.9 or s.10.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we answer the question framed thus The rent from the building will be computed separately from the income from the furniture and fixtures and in the case of rent from the building the appellant will be entitled to the allowances mentioned in sub-sec. 4 of s. 12

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct answer to referred question; integrates above holdings on s.10 rejection, s.12(4) applicability and inseparability.

holdings.text: The income from the hire of the furniture and fixtures was rightly assessed under s. 12 after providing for the allowances mentioned in sub-s. 3.

anchor.surface_text: To clear the ground it may be stated here that once s. 10 is found inapplicable to the case, there is no dispute that the income from the hire of the furniture and fixtures was rightly assessed under s. 12

holdings.reasoning_summary: No dispute; follows from mutual exclusivity post-s.10 rejection.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court judgment set aside. Rent from building assessed under s.12(4) with allowances per s.10(2)(iv),(v),(vi); hire from furniture and fixtures under s.12(3); no assessment under s.9 or s.10.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts of this case we are unable to agree that the letting of the building amounted to the doing of a business. The income under the lease cannot, therefore be assessed under s. 10 of the Act as the income of a business.

In the result we answer the question framed thus The rent from the building will be computed separately from the income from the furniture and fixtures and in the case of rent from the building the appellant will be entitled to the allowances mentioned in sub-sec. 4 of s. 12 and in the case of income from the furniture and fixtures, to those mentioned in sub-s 3 , and that no part of the income can be assessed under s. 9 or under s. 10.

anchor.surface_text: Now, it is beyond dispute that the several heads of income mentioned in s. 6 of the Act and dealt with separately in ss. 7 to 12 are mutually exclusive, each head being specific to cover the income arising from a particular source and that it cannot be said that any one of these sections is more specific than another-.

In the result we answer the question framed thus The rent from the building will be computed separately from the income from the furniture and fixtures and in the case of rent from the building the appellant will be entitled to the allowances mentioned in sub-sec. 4 of s. 12 and in the case of income from the furniture and fixtures, to those mentioned in sub-s 3 , and that no part of the income can be assessed under s. 9 or under s. 10.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that when a building and plant, machinery or furniture are inseparably let the Act contemplates the rent from the building as a residuary head of income.
